qas.question: Serbo-Croatian is the only Slavic language to use what two scripts together?
Which version, Latin or Cyrillic, is most commonly used?
How many extra letters does the Croatian Latin alphabet have?
How did Ljudevit Gaj define the Cyrillic alphabet?
How often is the Zagreb script used?
What is standard Latin represented as in the Rjecnik hrvatskog ili srpskog jezika?

plausible_answers.text: the former Yugoslav Academy of Sciences and Arts in Zagreb

qas.question: What group published the Latin and Cyrillic scripts?
How is Polish used in the literary standard?

context: The Croatian Latin alphabet (Gajica) followed suit shortly afterwards, when Ljudevit Gaj defined it as <b3_0>standard Latin<b3_0/> with <a2_0>five<a2_0/> extra letters that had diacritics, apparently borrowing much from Czech, but also from Polish, and inventing the unique digraphs "lj", "nj" and "dž". These digraphs are represented as <b5_0>"ļ, ń and ǵ"<b5_0/> respectively in the "Rječnik hrvatskog ili srpskog jezika", published by <b6_0>the former Yugoslav Academy of Sciences and Arts in Zagreb<b6_0/>. The latter digraphs, however, are <b7_0>unused<b7_0/> in the literary standard of the language. All in all, this makes Serbo-Croatian the only Slavic language to officially use both the <a0_0>Latin and Cyrillic<a0_0/> scripts, albeit the <a1_0>Latin<a1_0/> version is <b4_0>more commonly<b4_0/> used.
